topic.title: HP Helion OpenStack 2.0: Configuring the Centralized Logging Service

section.p: In HP Helion OpenStack 2.0 you will have the option to configure the Centralized Logging service for your needs. The information contained here will assist in this process.

section.title: Main Configuration Files
section.p: Centralized Logging can be configured via the configuration files in the ~/helion/my_cloud/config/logging/ directory on the deployer. These files and their use are:

row.entry: Main configuration file for all centralized logging components
Default overrides for the elasticsearch init script
Default overrides for the logstash init script

section.title: General Configuration
section.p: The Centralized Logging service needs to have the proper amount of resources available to it in order to perform adequately for different scale environments. The base logging levels will be tuned during installation according to the amount of RAM allocated to your control plane nodes to ensure optimum performance.

row.entry: Amount of heap allocated to Elasticsearch
Amount of heap allocated to Logstash
Number of logstash threads to spawn

section.p: These values can be viewed and changed in the ~/helion/my_cloud/config/logging/main.yml file if you wish but you will need to run a reconfigure of the Centralized Logging service if changes are made.
section.note: The total process memory consumption for Elasticsearch will be the above allocated heap value plus any Java Virtual Machine (JVM) overhead.

section.title: Kibana Configuration
section.p: The access information for Kibana is defined in ~/helion/my_cloud/config/logging/main.yml and implemented in the Kibana configuration file ~/helion/my_cloud/config/logging/kibana-apache2.conf.j2.

row.entry: Username that will be required for logging into the Kibana UI
Password generated during installation that is used to login to the Kibana UI

section.title: Elasticsearch Configuration
section.p: Elasticsearch has a number of tunable options exposed in its configuration that we have taken advantage of to tune Elasticsearch in HP Helion OpenStack in such a way that we favor indexing speed over search speed. We have also tuned it for optimal performance in low RAM environments. The options that we've modified are listed below along with an explanation as to why they were modified.
These configurations are defined in ~/helion/my_cloud/config/logging/main.yml and are implemented in the Elasticsearch configuration file ~/helion/my_cloud/config/logging/elasticsearch.yml.j2.

row.entry: Name of the Elasticsearch cluster. This variable cannot be changed after the initial deployment. Doing so will reset all Elasticsearch indices.
By default, this setting is unboundedâ€”Elasticsearch will never evict data from fielddata, which is less than ideal when trying to conserve on memory usage.
The field data circuit breaker allows Elasticsearch to estimate the amount of memory a field will require to be loaded into memory. This value must be greater than cache.size to evict data properly.
The number of expired docs to delete at once.
By default, this setting is -1 (i.e. never expires).

entry.p: All of the Monasca logging is defaulted to WARN. To change the level for all of our services you can run:
entry.codeblock: cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts monasca-reconfigure.yml -e "monasca_log_level=DEBUG" ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts monasca-agent-reconfigure.yml -e "monasca_log_level=DEBUG"
entry.p: If you want to change the logging level per service, each of the following files have the variable that you can set to the desired level:
entry.codeblock: ~/helion/hos/ansible/roles/monasca-persister/defaults/main.yml ~/helion/hos/ansible/roles/zookeeper/defaults/main.yml ~/helion/hos/ansible/roles/storm/defaults/main.yml ~/helion/hos/ansible/roles/monasca-notification/defaults/main.yml ~/helion/hos/ansible/roles/monasca-api/defaults/main.yml ~/helion/hos/ansible/roles/kafka/defaults/main.yml ~/helion/hos/ansible/roles/monasca-agent/defaults/main.yml (This one you will need to add the variable)
entry.p: You will then need to run:
entry.codeblock: cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts monasca-reconfigure.yml -e "monasca_log_level=DEBUG" ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts monasca-agent-reconfigure.yml -e "monasca_log_level=DEBUG"
